channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russian Forces Regroup, Focusing Efforts on Strategic Targets
item.description: Russian troops are consolidating their positions in key spots and resisting Ukrainian attempts to break their grip, while focusing fully on seizing Mariupol. Officials warned that Russia may try to divide Ukraine by consolidating territory in the east and south.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers inside a destroyed government building in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: The Making of Vladimir Putin
item.description: Tracing Putin’s 22-year slide from statesman to tyrant.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during a New York Times interview in 2003.

item.title: Blinken to Press Mideast Allies for Stronger Support for Ukraine
item.description: The countries, which have their own relationships with Russia, have provided some modest backing, but Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken will ask for more.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on Capitol Hill last year. While in the Middle East this week, he will be discussing “various means of support that Israel and other countries can give to Ukraine.”

item.title: Zelensky, Roots in Show Business, Presses for an Oscar Appearance
item.description: The Ukrainian president is looking for support from Hollywood. But his appeal to speak during the Oscars has encountered drama of its own.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volodymyr Zelensky on set during the filming of his television show “Servant of the People” in February 2019.

item.title: At the Edge of Kyiv, a Look at Ukraine’s Counteroffensive
item.description: Destroyed tanks and body parts are all that are left of a Russian advance, part of the larger battle to block the invaders’ attempt to enter or encircle the capital.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier near the remnants of a Russian T-90 tank that was said to have been destroyed with U.S.-made Javelin missile at a front-line position in the northern outskirts of Kyiv, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: In a Fiery Speech, Biden Warns of a Battle Between ‘Liberty and Repression’
item.description: The president warned Western nations that the fight against autocracy would be costly and could be lengthy.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, David E. Sanger and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: President Biden, speaking in Warsaw, said, “We need to steel ourselves for the long fight ahead.”

item.title: How Ukrainians Are Using Social Media to Stir Resistance
item.description: Photos and videos of the war’s horrors have spread quickly, searing into the global public consciousness and providing powerful ammunition in the information battle.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Empty strollers were placed in Lviv, Ukraine, last week to represent the children who had been killed during Russia’s invasion.

item.title: Mexico’s New International Airport Is Not Quite Ready for Takeoff
item.description: Mexico’s president inaugurated the first of a series of long-promised infrastructure projects — possibly a little too soon.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Elda Cantú
item.media:description: The control tower at Felipe Ángeles International Airport, north of Mexico City, during the inauguration ceremony on Monday.

item.title: Retired Doctor’s Protest Gets Attention of Spanish Banks
item.description: A campaign by a 78-year-old retired doctor with Parkinson’s disease against banks closing branches and moving services online resonates with a rapidly aging Spanish population.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carlos San Juan de Laorden at his bank in Valencia.

item.title: Prince William and Kate Middleton’s Caribbean Tour Marred By Gaffes and Miscues
item.description: The trip by Prince William and his wife, Catherine, the duchess of Cambridge, dramatized how rapidly Queen Elizabeth II is losing her grip on distant dominions where she is still head of state.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince William and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, in Kingston, Jamaica, on Tuesday.

item.title: Yemeni Rebel Attack in Jeddah Sets Saudi Oil Facility Ablaze
item.description: Saudi officials accused Yemen’s Houthi rebels of launching the attack, which cast a shadow over a Formula One car race aimed at international spectators.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: A fireball engulfs an Aramco oil depot near the Formula One circuit in Jeddah after the Houthi attack on Friday.

item.title: China and Solomon Islands Draft Secret Security Pact
item.description: The leaked agreement, if signed, could help the Chinese Navy block shipping routes that played a vital role in World War II.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Li Keqiang, left, the Chinese premier, and Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare of the Solomon Islands reviewing an honor guard during a ceremony in Beijing in 2019.

item.title: Ukraine Tries to Seize Momentum With Claims of Counteroffensive
item.description: The picture on the ground is muddy and it’s unclear how much territory Ukraine has gained back. But its announcement of a counteroffensive has enhanced the notion that it is taking the fight to the enemy.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lt. Tetiana Chornovol, commander of an anti-tank missile unit, on the outskirts of Kyiv earlier this month.

item.title: With U.S. Focus on Ukraine, North Korea Launches a Powerful New ICBM
item.description: It was the country’s first long-range ballistic missile test since 2017, and it raised the specter of intensified provocations and threats on the Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: News coverage in Seoul on Thursday, after North Korea carried out its latest missile launch.

item.title: How One Month of War in Ukraine Ground to a Bloody Stalemate
item.description: In four weeks, huge numbers of civilians have been bombed and displaced, but Russia has so far achieved almost none of its military objectives, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke from a Russian strike in Kyiv on Wednesday. Cities and towns across the country are being bombarded daily by Russian forces.

item.title: Ethiopia Declares ‘Humanitarian Truce’ in War-Ravaged Tigray Region
item.description: The conflict, now lasting 17 months, has left thousands dead, millions displaced and hindered aid from reaching those going hungry in the country’s northern region.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Simon Marks
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bus carrying civilians passing a destroyed tank outside Mekelle, the capital of Ethiopia’s Tigray region, in June 2021.

item.title: Zelensky Gives Interview to Russian Journalists. Moscow Orders It Quashed.
item.description: The remarkable interview was still published by journalists outside of Russia, an episode that laid bare the extraordinary, and partly successful, efforts at censorship by Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine spoke with some prominent members of the Russian media via video on Sunday.

item.title: As Ukraine War Moves Into 2nd Month, Fears Grow of Mariupol’s Fall to Russia
item.description: Ukraine’s top military intelligence officer suggested that Russia was changing its military focus to the south and east and might be trying to divide the country.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:description: Charred cars and a heavily damaged apartment building on Sunday in Mariupol, Ukraine, which was in increasingly dire straits.

item.title: In Lviv, New Russian Strikes Pierce the Sense of Security in West
item.description: Residents in the western city of Lviv once ignored the air raid sirens. But Russian rocket attacks over the weekend have brought the war closer to their doorstep.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters at a fuel storage facility that was struck by a Russian missile in Lviv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Arab Gunmen Kill 2 in Hadera, on Eve of Historic Summit
item.description: The unusually brazen attack in Hadera, a city on the Mediterranean coast, came as four Arab foreign ministers arrived for an unprecedented summit that shows Israel’s growing role in the Middle East
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Police officers collecting evidence at the scene of an attack in Hadera, Israel, on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Recalibrates Its Attack
item.description: Plus a historic summit in Israel and economic turmoil in Sri Lanka.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers with anti-tank weapons near the front lines north of Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: American Officials Try to Walk Back Biden’s Comments on Putin
item.description: Senior officials, including Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, and top lawmakers stressed that the United States was not seeking regime change in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane, Chris Cameron and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: President Biden’s remark in a speech in Warsaw that President Vladimir V. Putin “cannot remain in power” was not meant as a call for regime change, U.S. officials said Sunday.

item.title: Shanghai Imposes Staggered Lockdown, District by District
item.description: Unlike other Chinese cities, Shanghai had never before imposed a full-scale citywide lockdown, but the current measure comes close.
item.dc:creator: John Liu
item.media:description: An area of Shanghai that had already been under lockdown on Saturday.

item.title: Éric Zemmour Vows to Fight for Identity and Prosperity
item.description: Éric Zemmour, a far-right pundit, tried to revive his flagging campaign Sunday in a place that is familiar to hopefuls of his ilk.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Éric Zemmour drew a large crowd at a rally on Sunday in Paris, but his campaign for the French presidency has stumbled in recent weeks.

item.title: Putin Says Tchaikovsky Is Being Canceled. The Met Opera Disagrees.
item.description: The company’s revival of “Eugene Onegin” gives the lie to the Russian president’s claim that his country’s composers are suffering in the West.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Woolfe

item.title: Ukraine’s Warning
item.description: Russia’s war in Ukraine is especially dangerous after decades of relative peace worldwide.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: A Ukrainian flag flies above an illuminated peace sign during a protest against the Russian invasion of Ukraine near EU headquarters in Brussels last week.

item.title: Britain’s Old War Office Will Soon Become a 5-Star Raffles Hotel
item.description: An extravagant conversion is nearly complete on the Old War Office, an Edwardian-era monument to Britain’s imperial past being made into a five-star hotel and high-end apartments.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The historic Old War Office building on Whitehall in London.

item.title: One Story Filled Almost the Entire Magazine. It Came Together in Two Weeks.
item.description: The Ukrainian photographer Alexander Chekmenev captured portraits of Ukrainian citizens that appear in a new photo essay.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: China Plane Crash: Second ‘Black Box’ Is Found, Officials Say
item.description: The cause of the crash of China Eastern Flight 5735, which killed 132 people on Monday, remains unknown.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Recovering debris from the China Eastern Flight 5735 crash site in the Guangxi region of southern China on Thursday.

item.title: Zelensky renews his call for planes and tanks from NATO.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: In a picture obtained by Reuters from social media on Saturday, Russian soldiers and armored vehicles stood guard in the distance as dozens of residents of Slavutych, Ukraine, chanted, “Glory to Ukraine.”

item.title: Lin-Manuel Miranda to Miss Oscars After Wife Tests Positive for Virus
item.description: Mr. Miranda is up for an Academy Award for the song “Dos Oruguitas” from the Disney musical “Encanto.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Giang
item.media:description: Lin-Manuel Miranda during the Tony Awards show in New York City in September.

item.title: Afghan Refugees in U.K. Still in Limbo as Ukrainians Arrive
item.description: Some 12,000 Afghans who fled to Britain have been living in hotels for months awaiting permanent housing. This has raised questions about the country’s ability to take in many more escaping Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eid Mohammed, an Afghan refugee, with two of his sons in one of the two adjoining hotel rooms that houses the family of seven south of London.

item.title: Biden’s Barbed Remark About Putin: A Slip or a Veiled Threat?
item.description: The conclusion of Mr. Biden’s speech on Saturday was a reminder of how precarious diplomacy can be when bombs are already dropping.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden speaking at the Royal Castle in Warsaw on Saturday.

item.title: A History of the Tensions Between Ukraine and Russia
item.description: Here is a look at some key events in the run-up to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protests in Kyiv’s main square in 2014 were a violent flash point in relations between Ukraine and Russia.

item.title: Mélenchon, a Fiery Leftist, Has Late Surge in French Election
item.description: Jean-Luc Mélenchon, a skilled orator and veteran politician, hopes to become the first left-wing candidate since 2012 to reach the second round of France’s presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Jean-Luc Mélenchon at a campaign rally in Montpellier, France, in February.

item.title: What Did Biden Say About Russia?
item.description: Speaking in Warsaw, President Biden described Vladimir V. Putin as a tyrant with “a craving for absolute power and control.”
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: “Today, Russia has strangled democracy and sought to do so elsewhere,” President Biden said in a speech outside Warsaw’s Royal Castle in Poland.

item.title: China Eastern Crash Killed All 132 on Flight
item.description: Investigators were still looking for wreckage, remains and the second black box in an effort to determine what caused the crash.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Emergency workers at the scene of the crash earlier this week.

item.title: What to Know About Israel’s Summit With 4 Arab Countries
item.description: Four Arab foreign ministers will meet in Israel’s Negev desert on Sunday, along with their U.S. counterpart. The talks mark a realignment of Middle Eastern powers, accelerated by the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Naftali Bennett last month during the first visit to Bahrain by an Israeli prime minister.

item.title: Biden Calls Putin a Butcher After Meeting With Ukraine Refugees
item.description: His comment came as he visited a stadium in Warsaw where the Polish authorities are assisting the waves of people who are fleeing Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden, who met with Ukrainian refugees in Warsaw on Saturday, said the children asked for him to pray “for my dad, or my grandfather, and my brother,” who remain in Ukraine.

item.title: Zelensky Urges Energy Producers to Increase Exports to Europe
item.description: “The future of Europe rests with your efforts,” Ukraine’s leader said in a plea to help the continent wean itself off Russian fossil fuels.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Ras Laffan Industrial City, Qatar’s principal site for the production of liquefied natural gas and gas-to-liquid, about 50 miles north of the capital, Doha, in 2017.

item.title: An Oscars Preview
item.description: The 94th Academy Awards are tomorrow night. We have a guide.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Margaret Atwood on National Myths and the Roots of Totalitarianism
item.description: The Canadian author, whose dystopian novels fit with how many people feel about this moment, spoke on “The Ezra Klein Show.”
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Arden Wray for The New York Times
item.media:description: Margaret Atwood has written at least 17 novels, 20 books of poetry, along with short stories and countless essays.

item.title: Mideast Feels the Pinch of Rising Food Prices as Ramadan Nears
item.description: Russia’s war on Ukraine has driven up the prices of staple foods and energy across the Middle East and North Africa ahead of the Muslim holy month of daytime fasting and nighttime feasting.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: Egyptians bought bread in Cairo this month. Russia’s war on Ukraine has driven up the price of wheat.

item.title: Tyler Jacob of Minnesota Is Released After Being Held by Russian Troops
item.description: Tyler Jacob was taken off a bus by Russian soldiers at a checkpoint in Crimea, his mother said. He had been teaching English in the Ukrainian city of Kherson.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Tyler Jacob in an undated photo provided by his mother, Tina Hauser.

item.title: Public Health Catastrophe Looms in Ukraine, Experts Warn
item.description: Even before the war, the country struggled with epidemics of H.I.V., tuberculosis and hepatitis. The conflict threatens to undo decades of progress.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: An aid tent in Kyiv in the aftermath of an explosion at a residential complex on Sunday. Officials fear that wartime conditions will lead to new waves of infectious disease, as well as deaths resulting from lost care.

item.title: A Desperate Escape From Mariupol
item.description: Ukrainian families are taking enormous risks to try to flee Mariupol, traveling through Russian checkpoints — and in some cases land mines — to try to get to safety.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Ben Laffin and Benjamin Foley
item.media:credit: Benjamin Foley for The New York Times

item.title: New York’s mayor faces a backlash over a vaccine exemption for athletes.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrick J. Lynch, president of the Police Benevolent Association of New York, called the mayor’s exemption a double standard.

item.title: The Biden administration plans to offer a second booster shot to older Americans.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Administering a Covid-19 booster shot at Meritus Medical Center, in Hagerstown, Md., last month.

item.title: More Russian Mercenaries Deploying to Ukraine to Take On Greater Role in War
item.description: At least 1,000 fighters from Russia’s Wagner Group are expected to focus on the Kremlin’s goal of seizing eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: A Ukrainian Army member in the eastern Luhansk region, where more mercenaries are expected to head.

item.title: Kip Hawley, Transportation Security Administrator, Dies at 68
item.description: He sought to overhaul a much-maligned federal agency by enhancing security procedures, bolstering morale and taking a common-sense approach to the job.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:description: Kip Hawley in 2006, a year after he was named the Transportation Security Agency’s fourth administrator. He stayed through the end of the George W. Bush administration.

item.title: Just Weeks After Fleeing Ukraine, Woman Wins Jerusalem Marathon
item.description: Valentyna Vereteska fled from Mykolaiv, Ukraine, to Poland with her 11-year-old daughter a month ago.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:description: Valentyna Vereteska finished first in the Jerusalem Marathon on Friday.

item.title: Conger Ice Shelf Collapses in East Antarctica, a First
item.description: Scientists say a period of unusual weather, combined with record-low sea ice, led to the disintegration of the Conger ice shelf.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: U.S. National Ice Center, via Agence France-Presse —Getty Images
item.media:description: A satellite image taken over East Antarctica on March 17 shows the largest fragment of the collapsed Conger ice shelf, an iceberg named C-38.

item.title: Dagny Carlsson, Centenarian Blogger, Dies at 109
item.description: She began posting about her daily life in Sweden at the age of 99. She went on to acquire a worldwide fan base.
item.dc:creator: Annabelle Williams
item.media:credit: Anders Wiklund/TT NEWS AGENCY, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dagny Carlsson in 2017. Fans of her blog, which she began when she was 99, thanked her for teaching them, as one wrote, “that it is never too late to start living and thinking positively.”

item.title: Russia Signals Redefined Goals in Ukraine War as Its Advances Stall
item.description: The Russian Defense Ministry suggested its forces would concentrate on securing the eastern part of Ukraine, where Kremlin-backed separatists have long been fighting.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Michael D. Shear and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Russian-backed forces in Dokuchaievsk, in the eastern Donestsk region of Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Putin Goes Into Battle on a Second Front: Culture
item.description: In a blast against “cancel culture,” he said the West is “canceling” Russia by going after “an entire thousand-year-old country, our people.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia delivering an address Friday on "cancel culture” that was broadcast nationwide.

item.title: Ukrainians Fill Streets With Music, Echoing Past War Zones
item.description: In subway stations and apartment buildings, artists are playing Bach, Vivaldi and folk songs.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: Vera Lytovchenko has been giving impromptu concerts in the basement of her building in the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, where bombs have forced people to shelter.

item.title: British Museum to Remove Sackler Name From Its Walls
item.description: The decision comes just months after the Metropolitan Museum of Art said it would remove the family’s name from seven exhibition spaces.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: The facade of the British Museum in London.

item.title: Europe and the U.S. Make Ambitious Plans to Reduce Reliance on Russian Gas
item.description: President Biden said the United States would send more natural gas to Europe, though he did not specify how given that the U.S. is already near its export capacity.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:description: President Biden and Ursula von der Leyen of the European Commission announced that the U.S. would help the European Union secure an additional 15 billion cubic meters of liquefied natural gas this year.

item.title: Vera Gissing, Who Was Rescued by ‘Britain’s Schindler,’ Dies at 93
item.description: She was not quite 11 when train convoys organized by a London stockbroker carried her and hundreds of other Jewish children from Czechoslovakia on the eve of World War II.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: In Speech to E.U., Zelensky Singles Out Hungary Over Sanctions
item.description: Addressing the Hungarian leader, Viktor Orban, directly, Volodymyr Zelensky said, “You have to decide for yourself who you are with.”
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary arriving in Brussels on Thursday.
